alert.note: Alert for Western Kenai Peninsula; Western Prince William Sound (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 03 at 4:23PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR A GLACIER-DAMMED LAKE OUTBURST IN EFFECT UNTIL 230 PM AKDT THURSDAY FOR SNOW RIVER TO KENAI LAKE AND DOWN THE KENAI RIVER TO SKILAK LAKE... * WHAT...Flooding caused by a glacier-dammed lake outburst continues. * WHERE...Including the following areas, the Snow River, Kenai Lake, and the Kenai River from Kenai Lake to Skilak Lake. * WHEN...Until 230 PM AKDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Water will flow over Primrose Road (leading to Primrose Campground), likely becoming impassable to small vehicles and affecting campground access. Garages along Primrose Road may begin to flood. Water levels are expected to steadily rise tonight through Sunday and peak sometime Sunday night or Monday morning. Sterling Highway Residences from Milepost 48 to 50 could see water in their yards. Cooper Landing boat launch "fish walk" could become submerged. Potential flooding of Quartz Creek boat ramp and adjacent campsites. Water levels in these areas are expected to crest Monday night or Tuesday. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 421 PM AKDT, Based on rising Snow River water levels and downstream water temperature we believe the Snow Glacier Dammed Lake has begun to release. Water levels on Snow River just upstream of Kenai Lake have risen 1.5 feet since 30 August. The hydrographic trend continues to rise steeply in the absence of relative precipitation. Typically Snow Glacier Dammed Lake releases every other year; the last release was in October 2020. Current water level on the Snow River is above 11 ft, gage datum, and is expected to rise an additional 2-3 feet with a crest near 13 ft early Monday. At this time we expect Snow River water levels to exceed bankfull, but well below flood stage (16 ft, gage datum). Residents near the Snow River and the Kenai Lake confluence and Kenai Lake outlet should monitor local conditions and prepare for rising water levels. Current water level on the Kenai River at Cooper Landing is above 11 ft, gage datum, and may be just starting to rise. At this time, we anticipate a peak 4-5 ft higher than present water level. The forecast models suggest that by late Sunday, Kenai Lake outlet will reach Minor flood stage (13 ft, gage datum) and rise another 1 to 3 feet before the flood peak crests early Tuesday. Water level recession from flood stage should continue through the middle of the week before dropping below bank. The flood wave is expected to dissipate by lake effects with only minor water level rises below Skilak Lake and no flood impacts. - Inherent uncertainty in initial glacier lake volume will result in varying crest height and timing. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.

area.areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula; Western Prince William Sound
